result.execSummary:
The defendant Keith Clarence Smith Jr. was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case. One or more other charges in this case were dismissed. The dismissed charges were not proven and have no legal effect. Keith Clarence Smith Jr. is presumed innocent of the dismissed charges.

  • Keith Clarence Smith Jr. was found guilty of Disorderly Conduct, a class B misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 947.01(1).
  • Keith Clarence Smith Jr. was found guilty of Operate Firearm While Intoxicated, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 941.20(1)(b).
  • Keith Clarence Smith Jr. was found guilty of Resisting or Obstructing an Officer, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 946.41(1).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: Huber release if in compliance with the jail rules and regulations.

If probation is revoked and a prison term is not ordered or if probation is discharged/terminated, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant and in favor of restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  Collection may include income assignment.

miscConds.notes:
Provide DNA sample on 12-21-15.
Contact Veteran Service Officer to arrange contact with Veteran's Court.  Must comply with all terms and conditions of the Veterans' Court.  If accepted into the Court, their terms will be the conditions.
Must contact Veteran's Court by end of 2015.  
If not accepted into Veteran's Court, the conditions of probation will be as follows:
Any counseling, treatments and follow through including AODA assessments as determined by agent.
Absolute sobriety - no alcohol, no drugs, no prescription drugs without a valid prescription and taken only as prescribed and as approved by agent.
May not be in any establishment whose primary purpose is the sale of alcohol.
